channel.title: Projects on Academic
channel.description: Recent content in Projects on Academic

item.title: Open source academic projects, softwares and scripts
item.description:
There are some open academic projects, softwares and scripts which are developed by me. The projects included my github repositories. The softwares are used for downloading satellit data easily, writing notebook for paper quickly and so on. The srcipts are about the geo-visualization and based on R, Python or Javascripts. Futhermore, I will provide more different kinds of scripts.

D3L Tool of NASA Satellite

D3L Tool of NASA Satellite was developed by Mr. Dai . The program provides a graphical interface to download satellite imagery from NASA, such as MODIS products, MERIS and more. Due to new NASA Policies LAADS FTP servers (both public and private) will be shutting down around Monday, April 20th 2018. NASA provide some scripts to download, but it’s a little hard for some people who didn’t use python. So I have developed the D3L Tool of NASA Satellite.

  • Download Link

D3L Tool of NASA Satellite 1.0 (4/27/2018) for 64-bit Windows 8，10, Chinese Vesion

D3L Tool of NASA Satellite 1.0 (4/27/2018) for 64-bit Windows 8，10, English Vesion

D3L Tool of NASA Satellite 1.0 (4/27/2018) for 32-bit Windows 7，8，10 Chinese Vesion

D3L Tool of NASA Satellite 1.0 (4/27/2018) for 32-bit Windows 7，8，10 Chinese Vesion

Baidu Pan

  • Blog(in Chinese)

MODIS数据的简介和下载（六）——基于浏览器模拟登陆下载的方式以及D3L Tool开发

  • Official Website

D3L Tool of NASA Satellite

Note of Applied Statistics with R

This is some note of Applied Statistics with R which comes from my course ‘Applied Statistics’ at this term. The Note includes 14 Chapters. The note is in Chinese. Project,Book

Project Book

  • Introduction

In big data era, statistical theory is still meaningful. What’s deep learning study? “import tensorflow as tf”. Without basic statistical theory, we could not complete a very good study of deep learning or machine learning.

  • Download

Note-of-Applied-Statistics-with-R pdf

Note-of-Applied-Statistics-with-R mobi

Note-of-Applied-Statistics-with-R epub

Note-of-Applied-Statistics-with-R Baidu Pan

  • Acknowledge

We thanks Mr.Wang(CV) and her lessons: applied stastistics in University of Chinese Academic Sciences.

Junping Jia, Statistics (Fifth Edition), Renmin University of China Press, 2012.

Xiaoqun He, Multivariate Statistical Analysis (3rd Edition), Renmin University Press, 2012.

Geographical Detector for R

Due to the limitation of Excel software of geographical detector, I developed the Geographical Detector by R.

Geographical Detector Offical Website

More Detailed Information

We are fulfilling the information and software.

Scripts of Geovisualization

We will visualize the geographical features by R packages/Python library.

  • Remap(in R)

demo

The case study is visualization of the geographical tribune of youth.

  • Folium(in Python)

We visualize the raster(wind speed in Tibet) by folium. We also can use Heat map to visualize the points by folium(more informations can see the link of Heat Map). If you need this script of Heat Map, please send an e-mail to dsq1993qingge@163.com.

Heat Map

References

If you are using the softwares or scripts in paper, please cited as follow:

  • Shaoqing Dai. (2018). D3L Tool of NASA Satellite. doi:10.13140/RG.2.2.26178.63689
  • Shaoqing Dai. (2017). Spatial visualization demo in folium (for Python). doi:10.13140/RG.2.2.16320.23045

item.title: The application of RS, GIS and spatial statistics in geographical, ecological and environmental research
item.description:
Applications in geographical, ecological and environmental research

We used spatial analysis, spatial statistics and data mining to analyze the RS and GIS data in geographical, ecological and environmental research. Firstly, we used the Pearson correlation coefficient, generalized linear model, geographically weighted generalized linear regression model to analyze the impact of urban walking environment on robbery, snatch and theft crime (RST). Secondly, Regional soil quality issues arising from rapid urbanization have received extensive attention. Correlation, principle component analysis, cluster analysis and GeoDetector models were used to analyze the heavy metal sources in the soil accross an urbanization gradient. Thirdly, we used panel model to analyze the effects of command-and-control and market-oriented policy tools on China’s energy conservation and emissions reduction innovation. Forthly, some data mining technology was used to analyze urban spatial development pattern in beijing based on the big data of government. Finally, we developed a method to identify the urban ecological-production-living spaces and analyzed the high education staff’s refuge space under earthquake disater. These studies included criminal geography, heavy metal sources in soil, environmental economics, land use and disater, we used spatial analysis, spatial statistics and data mining in different topic researches. It’s very interesting.

Results

  • Influence of Walking Environment on Robbery, Snatch and Theft Crime in Urban Area, H City, China

Walking environment in urban

The visualization of correlation coefficient matrix and scatter plot

Spatial variation of regression coefficient of GWGLM

The results showed that the walking environment probably has a positive effect on the RST crime in H city, the greater walkability, the more RST. The effects of walking environment probably has spatial heterogeneity features both on RST and the residence probability of suspects.

  • Analysis of Heavy Metal Sources in the Soil of Riverbanks Across an Urbanization Gradient

The four groups (Cr-Ni-Cu, Cu-Zn-As-Sb, Cd and Pb) shared the same sources in the core urban region; five groups (Cr-Ni-Cu-Zn, As, Cd, Sb and Pb) in the suburbs and three groups (Cr-Ni, Cu-Zn-Cd-Sb-Pb and As) in the exurbs. GeoDetector methods not only validated the results of the three other methods, but also provided more possible impact factors. Besides the direct influences, the interaction effects among factors were quantified. Interactive combination with strong nonlinear increment changed from between-two-weak factors in the central region to between-strong-and-weak factors in the suburbs. In the exurbs, the stronger interaction effects were observed between strong and weak factors.

The spatial distribution of the heavy metal concentrations during the urbanization gradients

The inverse distance weighted (IDW) interpolated spatial patterns of Cd, Ni, Cu, Zn, As, Cd, Sb and Pb concentrations in the topsoil of the study area.

Numbers of nonlinear increase combinations in (a) urban core regions, (b) suburban regions, and © exurban regions. “Increase” means the comparison between the q value of interactions and the sum of two impact factors. “Increase 30–50%” low-level non-linear enhancement, “Increase 50–100%” means mid-level non-linear enhancement, “Increase >100%” means high-level non-linear enhancement

The combinations of interactive factors with nonlinear enhancements in the suburban area were fewer than in other urban gradient areas.

  • Research on the effects of command-and-control and market-oriented policy tools on China’s energy conservation and emissions reduction innovation

The category of market-oriented environmental regulation at provincial-level in 2014

Category Province Price
I Qinghai; Chongqing; Hunan; Heilongjiang; Tianjin; Hebei 1 514-1 650
II Shanxi; Xinjiang; Liaoning; Shandong; Jilin; Sichuan 1 651-1 787
III Shanghai; Guizhou; Hubei; Gansu; Guangxi; Beijing; Henan 1 788-1 972
IV Ningxia; Hainan; Jiangxi; Shaanxi; Yunnan; Jiangsu; Fujian 1 973-2 142
V Zhejiang; Anhui; Guangdong; Inner Mongolia 2 143-2 322
No data Tibet; Taiwan; Hong Kong; Macao

we can vaguely find out the spatial relationships between technology of ECER, command-and-control environmental regulation intensity, and marketoriented environmental regulation intensity. It may be due to the delay in the performance of environmental regulations and this paper constructed the static measurement model and measurement model so as to verify.

  • The Analysis of Urban Spatial Development Pattern in Beijing Based on the Big Data of Government

Influence distribution of annual variables geographical position grid on characteristics of LUP data in the second stage

We present a non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) method and recognize these patterns by using the land construction permission dataset. We find out two main developing patterns in these years, and made a series of analysis and explanation on both patterns by combining some additional information.

  • The identification of urban ecological-production-living spaces and urban resilience simulation optimization

We used multi-source data to identify the urban ecological-production-living spaces and provided some suggesstions for urban resilience simulation optimization. We developed some ArcGIS toolbox based on model builder and Python. Our results won the national third prize in the 2th big data supports spatial plannning and design competition.

  • The Optimization Model of High Education Staff’s Refuge Space Under Earthquake Disater

This is a report of fund by Fujian Normal University(cxxl-2014137). According to the spatial and temporal distribution of proposed model assumptions, in different time scales according to different locations of the evacuation route analysis. And the crowd under earthquake disaster evacuation of about 64.412m/min by using the MCE evaluation method and entropy method. According to the evaluation method of MCE results, the use of L-A network constraint model to evaluate campus earthquake evacuation capability. The whole campus evacuation capability is weak, scenario simulation refuge accommodate the number of students is 18638, the shelter utilization rate is only 30%. The need for further planning and construction of disaster prevention and mitigation.

References

  • 戴劭勍, 江辉仙, 李佳佳, 苏娴, 吴娟, and 任引. “H 市城区步行环境对两抢一盗警情的影响.” 地理科学 38, no. 8 (2018): 1235-1244.[Dai Shaoqing, Jiang Huixian, Li Jiajia, Su Xian, Wu Juan and Ren Yin. Influence of Walking Environment on Robbery, Snatch and Theft Crime in Urban Area, H City, China. Scientia Geographica Sinica 38, no. 8 (2018): 1235-1244.]
  • 戴劭勍. 2014-2015. 福建师范大学大学生创新创业训练计划(创新训练类)项目《地震灾害下高校人员避难疏散安置模型优化研究》(编号：cxxl-2014137).[Dai Shaoqing. 2014-2015. The Optimization Model of High Education Staff’s Refuge Space Under Earthquake Disater. Funded by Fujian Normal University(cxxl-2014137).]
  • Zuo, Shudi, Shaoqing Dai, Yaying Li, Jianfeng Tang, and Yin Ren. “Analysis of Heavy Metal Sources in the Soil of Riverbanks Across an Urbanization Gradient.” International journal of environmental research and public health 15, no. 10 (2018): 2175.5.
  • 叶琴, 曾刚, 戴劭勍, and 王丰龙. “不同环境规制工具对中国节能减排技术创新的影响——基于 285 个地级市面板数据.” 中国人口· 资源与环境 2 (2018): 13.
  • Ye, Qin, Shaoqing Dai, and Gang Zeng. “Research on the effects of command-and-control and market-oriented policy tools on China’s energy conservation and emissions reduction innovation.” Chinese Journal of Population Resources and Environment 16, no. 1 (2018): 1-11.
  • 李苗裔, 戴劭勍, 王静远, and 沈振江. “基于政府大数据的北京城市空间发展模式分析.” 地理信息世界 23, no. 3 (2016): 20-26.[Li Miaoyi, Dai Shaoqing, Wang Jingyuan, Shen Zhenjiang. The Analysis of Urban Spatial Development Pattern in Beijing Based on the Big Data of Government. Geomatics World 23, no. 3 (2016): 20-26.]

item.title: The carbon cycle at the urban scale based on integrating ecological process model and inventory emission account
item.description:
Accurate map of carbon sink by different methods

Firstly, we propose herein a low-cost method that combines machine learning and spatial statistics to construct a regional biomass map from non-representative sample units. Secondly, we scaled up an ecological process model to obtain the spatial distribution of regional biomass. Finally, we used some data assimilation technology by these data.

Results

The accuracy of different methods for biomass estimation

High resolution $CO_2$ emission gridded maps and urban form

Cities are the main sources of $CO_2$ emissions and, thus, must abate emissions responsibly. About 50% of urban $CO_2$ emissions was attributed to urban forms, mixed land use, building types, and transportation networks. It is necessary to characterize the pixel-based distribution of urban direct $CO_2$ emissions accurately. But large uncertainties was found at the urban scale, it’s important to analyze the uncertainties of $CO_2$ emissions gridded map at the urban scale. Besides, exlporing the relationship between $CO_2$ emissions and urban form is useful for planning.

Results

Comparison between our high resolution $CO_2$ emission gridding map and CHRED

detailed informations can see it

References

  • Shaoqing Dai, Shudi Zuo, Yin Ren. “High-resolution mapping of direct $CO_2$ emissions and uncertainties at the urban scale”. In Proceedings of Spatial Accuracy 2018. Beijing: Aussino Academic Publishing House. 2018: 88-90.
  • Shaoqing Dai, Xiaoman Zheng, Shudi Zuo, Yin Ren. “Improving the prediction accuracy of forest aboveground biomass benchmark map by integrating machine learning and spatial statistics”. In Proceedings of Spatial Accuracy 2018. Beijing: Aussino Academic Publishing House. 2018: 80-83.
  • Shudi Zuo, Shaoqing Dai, Yin Ren, and Zhaowu Yu. “Quantifying the linear and nonlinear relations between the urban form fragmentation and the carbon emission distribution.” In AGU Fall Meeting Abstracts. 2017.

item.title: The environmental effects of urban blue and green space
item.description:
Sponge city planning research in the view of landscape analysis

In the new normal period of economic transition in China, The Government came up with the concept of the Sponge City, we have some different views of sponge city planning The research extracted the impervious surface from the non-NGI(natural green infrastructure ) landscape and used the precipitation-volumetric method to simulate waterlogging scenarios. We determined the area of rainwater submersion by simulation experiments, the change in the NGI landscape by overlaying images of the region, and the association between these features by data mining. Using the change in ecology indices, we ascertained the changing spatial patterns of the NGI landscape and used these findings to formulate suggestions for Sponge City planning in Fuzhou. Overall, our work combines three research themes, urban waterlogging, landscape ecology, and data mining, for a deep analysis of the relationship between the NGI landscape and storm runoff in an urban environment.

Results

  • Submerged areas were characterized by high population densities and high levels of human activity.

Simulation results of storm water scenarios

Simulated parameter Scenario 1 Scenario 2
Storm intensity($L·S^{-1}·ha^{-1}$) 163.183 101.847
Runoff($L·S^{-1}$) 5.342×$10^6$ 6.668×$10^6$
Submerged depth(m) 3.943 4.055
Maximum submerged depth(m) 1.943 2.055
Submerged area ($km^{2}$) 1.345 6.032

The main submerged area in Fuzhou included the central business district. Numbers of people exposed to the submerged areas of scenarios 1 and 2 were 12,840 and 46,460 people, respectively.

Visual representation of simulation results for scenario 1 and scenario 2

  • Spatial association rule mining revealed a strong association between areas that were converted from NGI landscape and areas that were submerged in our simulations.

Results of association rule mining

Rules Support Confidence Lift
Submerged=>Change 0.002 0.212 1.655
Stay=>No Submerged 0.865 0.992 1.001

If an area was submerged, then the probability that the area was converted landscape was 21.2%. If an area was not subject to landscape conversion, then the probability that it would not be a submerged area was 99.2%.

How green space influence the fine particulate matter and urban heat island effect

The spatial distribution of green space will influence the fine particulate matter, land surface temperature, and other urban ecological process. The influence include direct and indirect effects. How to quantify the relationship between green space and environmental effects is so important. We combine ground observations, remote sensing and spatial statistics models to determine it. The results can provide some suggestions for policy makers.

Results

  • PM2. 5 Spatiotemporal Evolution and Drivers in the Yangtze River Delta between 2005 and 2015

The spatial distribution of changes in annual average PM2.5 concentrations in different YRD cities from 2005 to 2015

The proportion of level V concentrations continuously increased from 0.00% in 2005 to 7.75% in 2015, showing a rapid expansion trend in the YRD. The proportion of level I and level V concentration gradually increased from 2005 to 2010.

Annual average PM2.5 concentrations in different climate, ecosystem and geomorphological subregions (NS = North subtropical humid zone, CS = Central subtropical humid zone, AL = Arable land ecosystem, FL=Forest ecosystem, GL = Grassland ecosystem, WL = Water and wetland ecosystem, HS = Human settlement ecosystem, PL = Plain, TL = Tableland, HI = Hills, Mo1 = Small-undulating mountain, Mo2 = Mid-undulating mountain, Mo3 = Large-undulating mountain)

For the years 2005, 2010 and 2015, average PM2.5 concentrations were highest in the subregion of the human settlement ecosystem , followed by the farmland ecosystem and the wetland ecosystem . Average PM2.5 concentrations were highest in the north subtropic humid climate subregion and the central subtropic humid climate subregion . And finally, average PM2.5 concentrations were highest in the geomorphological plain subregion, followed by the platform subregion and the hilly subregion

  • Determining the Mechanisms that Influence the Surface Temperature of Urban Forest Canopies by Combining Remote Sensing Methods, Ground Observations, and Spatial Statistical Models

Spatial distribution of temperature in 2004 and 2014 obtained using a 2250 m threshold and local Getis–Ord Gi statistics. Red (GiZscore ≥ 1.65) indicates a hot spot, blue (GiZscore ≤ −1.65) indicates a cold spot, yellow (1.65 > GiZscore > −1.65) indicates a nonsignificant area, and gray indicates altitude. The numbers indicate the main regions of mutual conversion of cold spots, hot spots, and nonsignificant areas

The aggregated STUFC areas (absolute value of Z score ≥ 1.65 represents statistical significance) identified through the spatial statistical method were more suitable than the non-aggregated areas (1.65>Z Score>−1.65) to determine the relationship and mechanisms.

Influence (q value) of interactions in cold spot areas in 2004 and 2014

The environmental factors with interactions varied during different time periods. For instance, for the cold-spot area, the major interaction factors changed from DS in 2004 to ISP100 in 2014.

  • Individual and interactive influences of anthropogenic and ecological factors on forest PM2. 5 concentrations at an urban scale

Spatial distributions of urban forest PM2.5 concentrations on three different days at the optimal distance threshold of 3500 m

The spatial distributions of PM2.5 concentrations on 13 and 29 December 2014 and 14 January 2015 showed significant spatial clustering. The aggregated areas (hot spots and cold spots) of PM2.5 identified by Getis-Ord Gi* showed that PM2.5 hot spots were concentrated in urban centers and suburbs and cold spots were mainly distributed in the suburbs and exurban regions.

Scores for the interactive effects of impact factors sensitivity rankings at the three periods studied calculated based on simulations using multisource data (A is the result on 13 December 2014; B is the result on 29 December 2014; C is the result on 14 January 2015)

With the acceleration of urbanization, the interactive effects of population density, impervious surface percentage, and other factors could result in increased air pollution.

References

  • Shaoqing Dai; Jiajia Li; Shudi Zuo; Yin Ren, Huixian Jiang. Landscape-Scale Simulation Analysis of Waterlogging and Sponge City Planning for a Central Urban Area in Fuzhou City, China, International Low Impact Development Conference China 2016 : LID Applications in Sponge City Projects, 2017.
  • Yun, Guoliang, Yuanrong He, Yuantong Jiang, Panfeng Dou, and Shaoqing Dai. “PM2. 5 Spatiotemporal Evolution and Drivers in the Yangtze River Delta between 2005 and 2015.” Atmosphere 10, no. 2 (2019): 55.
  • Zuo, Shudi, Shaoqing Dai, Xiaodong Song, Chengdong Xu, Yilan Liao, Weiyin Chang, Qi Chen et al. “Determining the Mechanisms that Influence the Surface Temperature of Urban Forest Canopies by Combining Remote Sensing Methods, Ground Observations, and Spatial Statistical Models.” Remote Sensing 10, no. 11 (2018): 1814.
  • Yun, Guoliang, Shudi Zuo, Shaoqing Dai, Xiaodong Song, Chengdong Xu, Yilan Liao, Peiqiang Zhao et al. “Individual and interactive influences of anthropogenic and ecological factors on forest PM2. 5 concentrations at an urban scale.” Remote Sensing 10, no. 4 (2018): 521.

item.title: Virtual geographic environments and its applications
item.description:
The Virtual 3D model of Fuzhou Strait Olympic Sports Center

The National Winning Award on 2015 EsriCup National Collegiate Developed Contest in GIS·3D Modeling and Design.

Demo

Co-author: Minhang Ye, Ruitong Cheng, Haihan Zhuo

The research built up the virtual 3D model of Fuzhou strait olmpic sports center. At the same time, our research includes the planning of the surrounding infrastructure. Eespecially, we use City Engine to construct our variable model(different styles of building) to create greater values.

  • 3D model of Stadium

  • Different styles of buildings

  • Detection of illegal construction

The Simulation Model of Building Site Location and Construction Based on Data Augmented Design and BIM: A Case Study of Fujian Normal University

This is my undergraduate thesis. With the tide of Smart City and Big Data era, I explore the practice of Data Augmented Design、GIS and BIM in Smart Campus’s Application based on Fujian Normal University Keji Buildings.

  • Online Model

With the tide of Smart City and Big Data era, I explore the practice of Data Augmented Design、GIS and BIM in Smart Campus’s Application based on Fujian Normal University Keji Buildings. I build the simulation model of building site location and construction. And I use Data Augmented Design, GIS spatial analysis, Space Syntax and City Engine 3D modeling to support the building site location and assessment of planning, build the BIM model and develop the public participation GIS of Keji Buildings.

References

  • 戴劭勍. 2016 . 基于BIM与GIS的智慧校园规划选址与设计——以福建师范大学为例. 福州, 福建师范大学.[Dai Shaoqing. 2016. The Planning Location and Design of Smart Campus Based on BIM and GIS：A Case Study of Fujian Normal University. Fuzhou, Fujian Normal University.]
  • 戴劭勍. 2014-2015. 福建师范大学大学生创新创业训练计划(创新训练类)项目《地震灾害下高校人员避难疏散安置模型优化研究》(编号：cxxl-2014137).[Dai Shaoqing. 2014-2015. The Optimization Model of High Education Staff’s Refuge Space Under Earthquake Disater. Funded by Fujian Normal University(cxxl-2014137)]
